author: tokey1475
content: has there been any analysis on how 4488 will impact bandwidth reqs for node operators? i.e. how likely it is to push home network nodes over bandwith caps?

author: Deleted User
content: it most likely will unless it is restricted from serving blocks etc. but what is the purpose of home network nodes anyway.

author: tokey1475
content: the ability for individuals to run a node is a core feature of ethereum.  not to mention decentralization of validators on eth2

author: Deleted User
content: in my opinion home network nodes are lost cause

author: djrtwo
content: because they will not be able to run eventually? or because they are not able to run today?

author: .vbuterin
content: hmm, 1 MB per 12 sec is still not very much

author: .vbuterin
content: And lately bandwidth has been increasing much faster than CPU

author: .vbuterin
content: I guess it's the p2p overhead of lots of competing 100 kB+ transactions that's the issue?

author: Deleted User
content: it compounds does it not? i remember reading that bitcoin had this problem.

author: .vbuterin
content: what do you mean by compounding?

author: .vbuterin
content: In the long run, the solution to this is PBS

author: Deleted User
content: if you have 8 peers and you gotta serve them 1mb block each

author: .vbuterin
content: ah yes

author: .vbuterin
content: There are ways to mitigate that

author: .vbuterin
content: You can reduce redundancy to near-zero if you're willing to take a latency hit. Basically replace every block body send with "here's the hash, do you have it? No? ok here's the body"

author: .vbuterin
content: And uncle rates *are* low enough that we could afford the latency sacrifice in principle

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: You send the full block to sqrt(peers) and only send the block announcement to all other peers btw

author: .vbuterin
content: Right, you can take the hybrid route

author: tokey1475
content: im sure someone has better stats than me, but with 16 peers on geth i'm at ~110kb/s avg

author: Deleted User
content: is it fair to say that all else being equal EIP-4488 will increase bandwith use a potential 4-5x. Then its simply up for debate wether that will make home network node doable or not

author: .vbuterin
content: I know for me personally as a node-runner, the biggest constraint is disk space, the second biggest is computation; bandwidth is relatively minor by comparison

author: .vbuterin
content: So EIP-4488 actually brings the constraints back into "balance"

author: tokey1475
content: im in the same boat, but looking forward increasing disk space is much easier to deal with than exceeding bandwith limits

author: tokey1475
content: the reason i bring it up is that we may have a large cohort of first time node runners coming online with the merge

author: tokey1475
content: and the requirement to run your own execution client (many may be validating with infura now)

author: tokey1475
content: given the infrequency of rollup transactions right now it may be a non issue for the near term and can be dealt with along with 4444 for any diskspace issues
